Author: jansako#3330
Content: My number one trouble with crypto in general is that I am having trouble finding people that 'need' it. I work in a software dev company, even for us I am not able to find a clear use case where I could tell the owner something like: we should use blockchain tech to solve this business problem. I know he would jump on it, but so far I have been always able to find a 'better' (faster/simpler/less expensive)  approach, so we never needed it. TBH the 'I need to be safe from government/USD collapses tomorrow etc' stuff is just BS for most of businesses and especially the genpop out there

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Sure, IF the worst ever happens, the fringe will be vindicated but one should not build one's business model on the apocalypse incoming (unless one is selling survival equipment) 😃

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: Having money under your total control, accepted worldwide and sent in seconds, and market-driven instead of political, that is itself a great use case

Content: there was a pretty sensible article in Coindesk couple of days ago from a guy working for big four auditor EY. his main message was that even if it solves problems, it still too much hassle to change the existing systems that are already in place

Author: jansako#3330
Content: It must solve problems 'better' (faster, cheaper, easier) than the existing methods.

Author: crumb#2550

Author: jansako#3330
Content: The bigger the difference, the faster the adoption, but 'just enough better' is good, over time
